body:
i totally agree it's needed !!

i'm my case i want to share a folder and subfolder with different permissions.
example: 

mainfolder - shared without delete permission
mainfolder/folder1 - same as mainfolder
mainfolder/folder2 - add delete permission

for now we could share each subfolder separately but at least 2 problems comes up : 
1) we loose the hierarchy, all folder will be under shared folder
2) it will be very complicated to setup

unlike mtgap stated in #3515, i also think there is a way that this could be done easily. while this may not affect the casual user, if you use owncloud in a larger environment to collaborate, there are definitely scenarios for this. 

![subpermissions](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1753651/1171465/2003b812-2107-11e3-9add-716420a81ece.png)
this screenshot is from a folder that has been shared with a group and contains several subfolders. say i do not want a user from that group to see the folder "allgemein" (eng: general), we could add a triangle to the group that reveals everybody in it with checkboxes next to everyone. clearing the checkbox then would make that folder invisible to that user. something similar could be done if the top level folder was shared with individual users instead of groups.

@jancborchardt any thoughts on that idea?
i need also, is there the progress on this ?

i still think this would complicate things beyond being understandable for people.

your thoughts @karlitschek @mtrichards?

i think the issue is that we have two types of users. 1) filesystem guys and 2) dropbox guys
- to a dropbox type user, you have a folder, it has permissions, voila done.  
- to a filesystem style user, there is infinite flexibility in sub folder permissions and it makes things applicable to a lot of situations, but messy.

i can see use cases for complexity, but in general i try to avoid it or we will essentially reinvent a nice gui on top of a filesystem...that would be bad.

well, maybe the difference is semantic, but then you will also understand the problem:
dropbox guys = private users
filesystem guys = corporate users

1)private users - want something extremely simple - share a folder, and everything in it
2)corporate users - want to allow all users to have same folder structure, but limit access by role or specific user. a tiny bit of complexity is a good price to pay for having order.

for me, personally, it is too late - i moved to egnyte - mainly for this particular issue. they handle it marvelously.

btw, box (unlike dropbox) which is targeting corp users, has already agreed to adopt this view as well. and in upcoming version it will be supported.

i agree on this. in my case i need this feature because i'm testing owncloud for my company that's why i need permission to be flexible. it's a security issue.

now for a personal use (sharing with friends/family...) i wouldn't care so much about it.
you may define what you are targeting.

i'd like to add my support to this enhancement. 

exactly as outlined above, in a small corporate environment, i need to be able to manage a standardised folder structure with a range of access rights across the organisation.

permissions in their current form were fine when we started out with our business where everybody could see everything, and there was no need to manage data in a coherent fashion. now, the permissions setup is becoming a nightmare.

at present, using the differing access rights in different subfolders (with the widest access rights in the lowest level folder) is causing havoc in folder structures, and messy to manage intellectually! creating new folders for every user group is resulting in a proliferation of folders at the root share level, which is also not pretty.

i'll be following the further discussion closely, as i'd really like to back owncloud. however, this functionality will become quite critical for us quite soon...!

> creating new folders for every user group is resulting in a proliferation of folders at the root share level, which is also not pretty.

@omnimercador this will (hopefully) change with owncloud 7 where shared folders will not reside in a â»sharedâ« subfolder, but rather be movable anywhere you want. individually for every user (in short: like dropbox).

yes, the threads are #3224 (sharing dialog) and #4437 (sharing behavior). also #1936 (design forward: files) for the sidebar, where we could have filters to show: files shared with you, files shared with you read-only, files shared by you, files shared by you read-only, files shared via link etc.

we have to go step by step, and especially for sharing we donâ€™t have the groundwork set yet. so we shouldnâ€™t rush forward with more complex proposals like these. of course we need to keep them in the back of our heads but maybe something else we do on the way will solve large parts of the existing problem.

actually, the usage of non-inherited permissions (this is really the needed part) will allow to have exactly same folder tree for all across the enterprise using the owncloud. just show the folder name in the structure in case there is tree (shared folder -> restricted folder -> shared folder). the support is much easier, as admin will know what each user is viewing and having problems with.
this is a common issue how "normal" corporations are thinking of their folders trees:
http://www.egnyte.com/assets/images/illustrations/640px-permissions-architecture.jpg
just look how egnyte are doing that. this is exactly what is needed.
http://www.egnyte.com/ms/egnyte-vs-box/#folder-permissions
this is not to advertise egnyte â€“ i really like the open-source owncloud solution. but you need to learn from corp-oriented companies (for personal use free dropbox is more than enough)

i would like to voice my support for the initial proposal to solve this problem. in my opinion adding filters/search is an overly complex "solution" that doesn't solve the underlying problem. allow end-users to "mimick" the original folder structure or apply their own, doesn't solve the lack of control from a business perspective.
in terms of the arguments brought forward earlier ("way too complicated for user experience") i'm quite sure the filter/search approach is much more complicated and overwhelming compared to the "restricted access" method.

another use case description:
i'm looking to implement owncloud in a small enterprise environment. our various design and production documents have "hands-on" or "signed off & accepted" status (as required by certain iso standards). it would be kind of obvious to have both document types in their respective sub-folders of the module they are designs of. a designer working on module b would get read-only access to all "signed off" sub-folders for module b, and the components module b would depend on. he/she would get write access to the module b "hands-on" folder.

if i were to implement this use case using ownclouds current authorisation mechanism, it would require me to create two separate folder structures, one for the signed off documents, and one for the work-in progress documents. great fun if there are a couple dozen projects each with tens (sometimes hundreds) of components.
